title: An algebra problem by A Former Brilliant Member

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\text{Chance(Positivity) }=x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and so the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\text{Chance(Negativity) }=100-x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (assuming that the number isn't 0)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We have the equation:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100-x=x+\dfrac{100-x}{x}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Multiplying, and simplifying, we get:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2x^2-101x+100 = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Solving,
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = \dfrac{101 \pm \sqrt{101^2 - 4\cdot 2\cdot 100}}{4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Putting in our equation, we see that"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = \dfrac{101 + \sqrt{101^2 - 4\cdot 2\cdot 100}}{4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" satisfies the condition, so it is the answer.
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = \dfrac{101 + \sqrt{101^2 - 4\cdot 2\cdot 100}}{4} \approx 49.48"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Thank you for pointing it out! I was also wondering why I had cancelled that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Your equation has minor mistake. It should be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2x^2 - 101x + 100 = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" :)

replies.body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @A Former Brilliant Member – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" No Sir. I came to know about these Olympiads only a few months ago, I will try to appear for PRMO and NSEJS this year if I can. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Yes. Keep your cool while writing a solution. Have you appeared in RMO?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Oh sorry Sir. I had many typos and mistakes in the solution, is it ok now?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            You did a mistake in solving the quadratic equation. It should be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in the denominator. Check your final answer also. It is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\approx 49.489688"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solution 1:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4^{x+1}=8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^{2(x+1)}=2^3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2(x+1)=3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+1=\dfrac{3}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=\dfrac{3}{2}-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=\dfrac{3}{2}-\dfrac{2}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=\dfrac{1}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=0.5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large\color{#D61F06}\boxed{answer}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solution 2:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"taking the natural logarithm of both sides"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4^{x+1}=8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\ln~4^{x+1}=\ln~8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x+1)\ln~4=\ln~8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+1=\dfrac{\ln~8}{\ln~2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By the use of a calculator, we get"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+1=1.5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Finally,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=0.5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large\color{#D61F06}\boxed{answer}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 13 and 117

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            To answer your second question, Brian gave an example. 13 and 119: e^(13/e) is > 119, but 2.6^5 < 119.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I had the same approach in terms of estimation. It's interesting that there have to be exactly "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" numbers - both "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left(\frac{13}{4}\right)^4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left(\frac{13}{6}\right)^6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are too small. Are there any other sets of rationals that work? Are there infinitely many? Are there examples of similar questions where this estimation technique doesn't work? (ie we're looking for a set of rationals with sum "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", product "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P<e^{S/e}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", but none exists).

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Nice question. I first checked to see what the maximum product of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such rational numbers which added to 13 could possibly be. This is achieved when all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" numbers are the same value "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = \dfrac{13}{n}, n \lt 13"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". For a non-integral value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the maximum of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^{n} = \left(\dfrac{13}{n}\right)^{n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e^{13/e} \approx 119.4 \gt 117"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which prompted me to go ahead and guess 'Yes', but I wasn't able to prove to myself that this could be achieved with rational numbers only, as your example does. (Note that for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = 13/5 = 2.6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", roughly in line with your example, we get  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^{5} \approx 118.8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which suggests that any solution set would have to involve 5 rational numbers) I'll have to give this more thought. Anyway, a follow-up question would be the same but with 120 (or even 119) replacing 117, the answer to which would definitely be 'No'.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Partly answering my own question: the set "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2. \dot{2},2.6,2.7,2.7,2.\dot{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" also works.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
